channel.title: Science : NPR
channel.description: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Mozzarella Magic: How My Father And I Learned To Separate Curds And Whey
item.description: March 9, 2017 - To feed their cheese habit, the author and her father took a crash course in mozzarella on a Pennsylvania farm. The experience offered valuable insight into the science and history of cheese-making.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 9, 2017 - To feed their cheese habit, the author and her father took a crash course in mozzarella on a Pennsylvania farm. The experience offered valuable insight into the science and history of cheese-making. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/03/09/518337171/mozzarella-magic-how-my-father-and-i-learned-to-separate-curds-and-whey

item.title: Scientists Closer To Creating A Fully Synthetic Yeast Genome
item.description: March 9, 2017 - An international consortium of researchers has synthesized about a third of the genetic code of baker's yeast. It's an important milestone in science's quest to create complex "synthetic life."
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 9, 2017 - An international consortium of researchers has synthesized about a third of the genetic code of baker's yeast. It's an important milestone in science's quest to create complex "synthetic life." http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/03/09/518990577/scientists-closer-to-creating-a-fully-synthetic-yeast-genome

item.title: EPA Chief Scott Pruitt Questions Basic Facts About Climate Change
item.description: March 9, 2017 - In an interview with CNBC, President Trump's EPA administrator said he did not believe carbon dioxide is a major contributor to global warming.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 9, 2017 - In an interview with CNBC, President Trump's EPA administrator said he did not believe carbon dioxide is a major contributor to global warming. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/03/09/519425866/epa-chief-scott-pruitt-questions-basic-facts-about-climate-change

item.title: Trump, Democrats Look For Common Ground On Drug Prices
item.description: March 8, 2017 - Two congressmen met with President Trump seeking support for a bill to expand the government's ability to negotiate drug prices. But it's not clear it would have much impact or will gain support.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 8, 2017 - Two congressmen met with President Trump seeking support for a bill to expand the government's ability to negotiate drug prices. But it's not clear it would have much impact or will gain support. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/03/08/519306444/trump-dems-look-for-common-ground-on-drug-prices

item.title: Some Neanderthals Were Vegetarian — And They Likely Kissed Our Human Ancestors
item.description: March 8, 2017 - A new study of the dental plaques of three Neanderthals reveals surprising facts about their lives, including what they ate, the diseases that ailed them and how they self-medicated (and smooched).
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 8, 2017 - A new study of the dental plaques of three Neanderthals reveals surprising facts about their lives, including what they ate, the diseases that ailed them and how they self-medicated (and smooched). http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/03/08/519048010/some-neanderthals-were-vegetarian-and-they-likely-kissed-our-human-ancestors

item.title: Maybe You, Too, Could Become A Super Memorizer
item.description: March 8, 2017 - After six weeks of training, people could memorize twice as much. Areas of the brain had begun communicating in new ways — a lot like what happens inside the heads of world memory champions.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 8, 2017 - After six weeks of training, people could memorize twice as much. Areas of the brain had begun communicating in new ways — a lot like what happens inside the heads of world memory champions. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/03/08/518815297/maybe-you-too-could-become-a-super-memorizer

item.title: Researchers Take A Step Toward Mind-Controlled Robots
item.description: March 8, 2017 - Researchers have created a system where humans can guide robots with their brainwaves, signaling to the machines when they've made a mistake. It could help improve the way humans and robots interact.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 8, 2017 - Researchers have created a system where humans can guide robots with their brainwaves, signaling to the machines when they've made a mistake. It could help improve the way humans and robots interact. http://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2017/03/08/519235038/researchers-take-a-step-toward-mind-controlled-robots

item.title: Effects Of Global Warming On Display In Antarctica
item.description: March 8, 2017 - James McClintock, a marine biologist, talks with David Greene about how warming temperatures have had a dramatic impact on the glacier near the U.S. Palmer Station in Antarctica.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 8, 2017 - James McClintock, a marine biologist, talks with David Greene about how warming temperatures have had a dramatic impact on the glacier near the U.S. Palmer Station in Antarctica. http://www.npr.org/2017/03/08/519170712/effects-of-global-warming-on-display-in-antarctica

item.title: The Affordable Care Act, Medicaid And Divorce
item.description:
March 8, 2017 - As Republicans unveil their Affordable Care Act replacement, we examine how Medicaid expansion has affected divorce rates among older people.
- http://www.npr.org/2017/03/08/519170657/the-affordable-care-act-medicaid-and-divorce
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 8, 2017 - As Republicans unveil their Affordable Care Act replacement, we examine how Medicaid expansion has affected divorce rates among older people. http://www.npr.org/2017/03/08/519170657/the-affordable-care-act-medicaid-and-divorce

item.title: Public Clinics Fear Federal Cuts To Planned Parenthood Would Strand Patients
item.description: March 7, 2017 - A goal for many Republicans is to cut federal funding for health services at Planned Parenthood and divert those funds to public health centers. How ready are those centers to pick up that work?
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 7, 2017 - A goal for many Republicans is to cut federal funding for health services at Planned Parenthood and divert those funds to public health centers. How ready are those centers to pick up that work? http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/03/07/519017520/public-clinics-fear-federal-cuts-to-planned-parenthood-would-strand-patients

item.title: Texas City Leads The Way On Renewable Energy
item.description:
March 7, 2017 - Georgetown, Texas, an exurb of Austin, is one of the first cities in the country to be 100 percent powered by renewable energy.
- http://www.npr.org/2017/03/07/519064002/texas-city-leads-the-way-on-renewable-energy
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 7, 2017 - Georgetown, Texas, an exurb of Austin, is one of the first cities in the country to be 100 percent powered by renewable energy. http://www.npr.org/2017/03/07/519064002/texas-city-leads-the-way-on-renewable-energy

item.title: For Breast Cancer Survivors, Eating Soy Tied To A Longevity Boost
item.description: March 7, 2017 - New research finds eating soy milk, edamame and tofu does not have harmful effects for women with breast cancer, as some have worried. In fact, for some women, soy consumption was tied to longer life.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 7, 2017 - New research finds eating soy milk, edamame and tofu does not have harmful effects for women with breast cancer, as some have worried. In fact, for some women, soy consumption was tied to longer life. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/03/07/519030514/eating-soy-has-benefits-for-breast-cancer-survivors-study-finds

item.title: WATCH: Raindrops Catapult Bacteria Into The Air, And It's Beautiful
item.description: March 7, 2017 - They don't have wings, but bacteria sure can fly. Researchers at MIT say that tiny bubbles trapped by raindrops play a part in launching bacteria on long-distance flights.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 7, 2017 - They don't have wings, but bacteria sure can fly. Researchers at MIT say that tiny bubbles trapped by raindrops play a part in launching bacteria on long-distance flights. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/03/07/518811502/watch-raindrops-catapult-bacteria-into-the-air-and-its-beautiful

item.title: Are Routine Pelvic Exams A Must? Evidence Is Lacking, Task Force Says
item.description: March 7, 2017 - There's not enough good evidence to make the call as to whether an annual pelvic exam is a good screening tool, the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force says.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 7, 2017 - There's not enough good evidence to make the call as to whether an annual pelvic exam is a good screening tool, the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force says. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/03/07/518838706/are-routine-pelvic-exams-a-must-evidence-is-lacking-task-force-says

item.title: Farmers Fight Environmental Regulations
item.description: March 7, 2017 - Many of America's farmers are successfully fending off environmental regulation, from the Obama administration's Clean Water Rule to a lawsuit in Iowa that's aimed at reducing nitrates in rivers.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 7, 2017 - Many of America's farmers are successfully fending off environmental regulation, from the Obama administration's Clean Water Rule to a lawsuit in Iowa that's aimed at reducing nitrates in rivers. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/03/07/518841084/farmers-fight-environmental-regulations
